section-block.rac_book_caption: Book: Dentists and What They Do

section-block.rac_book_summary: This informational text teaches us about dentists and how they take care of our teeth. There are many opportunities for counting teeth and tools!

section-block.rac_body-text: Review rote counting from 1–30. Count aloud, encouraging the class to count along with you. Set a slow pace and point to the numbers on a number line, if available.
Have children stand in a circle. Start a clockwise count from 1–30. Encourage children to say the next number as fast as they can! Repeat, moving counterclockwise.

section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: This week we are going to read Dentists and What They Do by Liesbet Slegers.
You know that Lala loves all sorts of books, and that she loves to look for numbers in informational texts like this one!
There is a question I want you to think about as we read:
section.rac_guiding-question_blue: What is one thing a dentist does?

section.rac_body-text: Use Equity Sticks to choose children to answer the questions below.
Focus on Counting: Reinforce one-to-one correspondence by pointing to items on each page and counting them aloud one by one.
section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: Who has been to the dentist before? We’re going to read about a child’s visit to the dentist.
The dentist wears gloves. How many fingers are on this glove? Let’s count one by one!
The dentist cleans people’s teeth. She has many tools that help her. One of them is a probe with a little hook to feel for sore spots or holes in a tooth.
How many tools are in the blue picture? Let’s count!
Brushing your teeth twice a day is a good way to keep healthy. Children start with 20 baby teeth.
Let’s count to 20 together. 1, 2, 3...
The dentist took a tooth photo! How many teeth are in this photo? Let’s count!
Let’s talk about the guiding question:
section.rac_guiding-question_blue: What is one thing that dentists do?
section.rac_body-text: Guide children to Turn and Talk. Use Equity Sticks to choose several children to share their responses to the question.
Write and read aloud short sentences about what dentists do as children watch.

rac_support_challenge-box.rac_teacher-talk_blue: What tools does a dentist use to check and clean teeth?

section-block.rac_child_development_body: Rote counting is the base skill of all math concepts. Before you can add or subtract, you must know what the numbers are! Practice is key, especially for the teen numbers, as they do not follow the common pattern of number names (seven-teen, rather than ten-seven). Try to find opportunities to practice numbers 10–20 as often as you can.

section-block.rac_column_heds_no_paragraph_rule_day_2: Share the Mind Builder: Make and Keep Relationships

rac_body-text.rac_teacher-talk_blue: There are many kinds of relationships. We have friends we like to talk to and play with. We have family members who we love. We also have adults like teachers and dentists who help keep us healthy and safe. It’s important to keep our relationships strong by caring for and listening to the people we see often.

section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: Today we will reread Dentists and What They Do by Liesbet Slegers. We will talk about making and keeping relationships with adults we trust, like dentists.
Clifford has relationships with lots of different people! He loves to read books that show him ways to keep friendships and other relationships strong.

section.rac_column_heds_with_rule: Close-Read: Connect to the Mind Builder
section.rac_body-text: Focus on Cardinality: Ask children, How many in all? to ensure children understand that the last number said aloud indicates the number of items counted.
section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: Dentists make sure our teeth are healthy. We have an important relationship with our dentists—we visit their office to get our teeth checked and they tell us how to take care of our teeth. (MB)
What is it like when you go to the dentist?
Let’s count this dentist’s gloves. How many in all? Now, let’s count her shoes. Are there the same number of gloves and shoes? How can you tell?
This dentist has curly black hair. What does your dentist look like? What does she or he wear? (MB)
Let’s count the big teeth. How many in all? Now, let’s count the small teeth. Are there the same number of small teeth and big teeth? How can you tell?
The dentist is giving a “thumbs-up.” That means she is happy that the boy took care of his teeth!
How else can we show someone that we are happy? (MB)
What are the dentist and the boy doing in this picture? Waving goodbye is another way we can say something to our friends without using words. (MB)

section.rac_body-text: Have children choose a partner. Guide each child to ask questions to learn something new about their friend, like whether they have a pet at home or what their favorite food is. After partners talk, ask volunteers to tell the class one new thing they learned about their partners. Point out that listening to each other is an important part of having a good relationship.
Transcribe children’s speech as they talk about their friends.

section-block.rac_child_development_body: It is crucial for young children to develop an “environment of relationships.” Positive peer-to-peer and adult-to-child interactions lay the foundation for both academic success and mental health. Start by helping children refer to each other and you by name, and notice each other’s defining traits and features. Point out when someone is absent. (NSCDC, 2004)

section-block.rac_body-text: Hold up three Connecting Cubes, each a different color. Count the cubes aloud. There are three cubes in all. Then, count the cubes in reverse order. There are still three!
Put four Pattern Blocks in a bag as “dentist tools”. Invite children to pull the tools randomly from the bag and count them. How many in all? Do we always have four tools?

section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: Today we are going to reread Dentists and What They Do by Liesbet Slegers.
Lala loves reading true books about real information.
As we read today, I want you to think about this question: What is one thing the boy does when he goes to the dentist?

section.rac_body-text: Facilitate back-and-forth conversations with children to extend language.
section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: Let’s count the tools on this page! How many in all? Now let’s start with this tool. Are there still three tools, even though we counted in a different order?
The boy listens to the dentist! He drinks water when she tells him. Why is it important to listen to adults we trust? (MB)
The boy holds his stuffed animal while the dentist looks at his stuffed animal’s teeth.
Let’s count the patients, starting with the stuffed animal! How many in all? Now, let’s count starting with the boy. Are there still two patients?

The boy opens his mouth wide! How many teeth do you see? Let’s start counting on the top row. How many in all? Now, let’s count starting with the bottom row. Is the number of teeth the same? How can you tell?
What is the boy’s mom doing in this picture? How can we show adults and friends that we care about them? (MB)
Did you listen and remember as we read the story today? What is one thing the boy does when he goes to the dentist?
section.rac_body-text: Use Equity Sticks to ask several children to share their responses to the guiding question.
Share a pen with children as you draw and write together about what patients do at a dentist appointment.

rac_support_challenge-box.rac_teacher-talk_blue: What does the boy do so the dentist can see his teeth?
The boy opens his m____ (mouth) wide.
The boy opens his mouth wide.
What do you do when you go to the dentist?

section-block.rac_child_development_body: One important principle of counting is that the order that items are counted in is irrelevant. Help children understand that objects can be counted left-to-right, right-to-left, or randomly and that the same number will be reached, as long as every object in the set is given one count. Seeing this in practice reinforces the concept.

section-block.rac_body-text: Get children excited to learn about washing hands by counting all of the hands in the room. Have children stand in a circle and hold both hands in the center. Guide children to remove each hand from the circle as it is counted. Ask, How many in all? Next, have children switch places with a friend across the circle. Count all of the hands again. Are there still the same number of hands?

section.rac_column_heds_no_paragraph_rule: Share the Big Chart of Big Ideas
section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: This week we are going to read Keep Your Hands Clean. It is an informational poster full of facts.
Dentists and What They Do and Keep Your Hands Clean each focus on ways we can stay healthy. Let’s look for connections between the two as we read.
How can we stay healthy?

section.rac_body-text: Count to 20 aloud to show how long it should take to scrub your hands. Then, share the song and sing it together. Point out the steps on the Big Chart, stopping to ask these questions.
section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: Let’s count the hands in this picture! How many in all? Now let’s count again, starting with this hand. Are there still two hands?
It’s important to use soap so we can make sure our hands are very clean, just like we use toothpaste to make sure our teeth are clean.
This is how we scrub our hands! Let’s count to 20 together and pretend to scrub. Now, let’s sing the song!
This child is rinsing her hands. How can you tell?
How many steps are there when washing your hands? Let’s count, starting with the first step, “Wet hands.”
Now let’s count again, starting with the last step, “Dry hands.” Are there still five steps, even though we counted out of order?

section.rac_body-text: Encourage children to find a friend to be their partner. Have partners take turns teaching each other how to wash their hands. Guide children to follow the steps in the Big Chart, and sing the song as they scrub. (MB)
Provide a writing prompt about hand washing and give feedback as children draw and write in response to the prompt.

section-block.rac_child_development_body: Hand washing methods and beliefs can vary greatly among different cultures. In Hindu culture, ash or mud is used in place of soap, and has been proven to be just as effective. In Ghana, visitors traditionally wash their faces and hands before entering a home. Invite children to share any hand washing habits they have been taught by their families.

section-block.rac_body-text: Help children understand that there are different workers at school and in their neighborhood whose job is to keep them healthy and to help them take care of themselves. Understanding different community helpers and the services they provide is a beginning concept in economics. Invite children to name other community helpers that work to keep them healthy.
Challenge children to find items in the classroom that promote healthy habits, like a ball to represent exercise or pretend produce to represent healthy eating.

section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: Let’s reread Dentists and What They Do by Liesbet Slegers one more time this week.
Who remembers if this book tells us a story or teaches us information?
We have learned about many things that dentists do to keep our teeth healthy. When we read today, think about this question: What is one thing you can do to keep your teeth healthy?
When we reread the book, we will act out a visit to the dentist. Some of you will also come up to count the things we see in the book.
What does a dentist wear? Let’s pretend to be a dentist. Pull on the coat first, and then put on the mask.
The dentist is holding food that is healthy for your teeth. Let’s count how many yogurt cups the dentist is holding. Now, let’s count how many apples. Are the numbers the same? How can you tell?
The girl in the picture is brushing her teeth. The dentist looks happy. Why do you think the dentist is happy that the girl brushed her teeth? (MB)
Let’s pretend to brush our teeth! Count to 20 so we can make sure they’re clean.
How many times do you see the word tickle next to the gnome? Let’s count! Now, let’s count how many ears the gnome has. Are the numbers the same? How can you tell?
Let’s pretend to tickle teeth!
Let’s count the teeth in this photo, starting at the top. How many in all? Now let’s count from the bottom. Are there still six teeth? How can you tell?
Let’s pretend to take a tooth photo! Open your mouth wide, and snap a picture!
What is one thing you can do to keep your teeth healthy?
section.rac_body-text: Have children Turn and Talk. Use Equity Sticks to ask several children to respond to the guiding question.
section.rac_body-text_bulleted: I can go to the dentist.

section.rac_body-text: Invite children to draw or write a story about a visit to the dentist and share their work.

rac_support_challenge-box.rac_teacher-talk_blue: What can you eat to keep your teeth healthy?
Why is it important to keep your teeth clean?

section-block.rac_child_development_body: Although baby teeth fall out and are replaced by adult teeth, tooth decay in baby teeth can still lead to future dental problems. Preschoolers have a limited ability to take care of their own teeth, but you can coach them to create healthy habits and remind families to make brushing teeth part of their daily routine.
